children.name: to earn a lot of money
make a fortune b2
children.definition: make a fortunealsomake a bomb british /ˌmeɪk ə ˈfɔːʳtʃən, ˌmeɪk ə ˈbɒmǁ-ˈbɑːm/  to earn a very large amount of money:
examples: ▪ the person who invented post-it notes must have made a fortune.
make a fortune (by) doing something
▪ roger makes a fortune buying and selling real estate.
make your fortunebecome rich
▪ jules made his fortune in the liquor business.

children.name: earn/make good money a1
children.definition: earn/make good money/ˌɜːʳn, ˌmeɪk gʊd ˈmʌni/  to be paid a lot of money by the person or company you work for, or a lot of money from your own business:
examples: kiếm được nhiều tiền
▪ milos earns good money as a foreman.
▪ dan is making good money now, but for years we really struggled.

children.name: highly-paid/well-paid x
children.definition: highly-paid/well-paid/ˌhaɪli ˈpeɪd◂, ˌwel ˈpeɪd◂/  earning a lot of money:
examples: (ai đó ) được trả cao
▪ most engineers are very well-paid.
▪ dr. singh is one of the most highly-paid surgeons in britain.

children.name: rake it in x
children.definition: rake it in /ˈreɪk ɪt ɪn/  informal to earn a lot of money quickly:
examples: kiếm được nhiều ( nhanh chóng )
▪ athletes rake it in these days.
somebody must be raking it in
▪ what a car! jasper must be raking it in.

children.name: be overpaid x
children.definition: be overpaid/ˌəʊvəʳˈpeɪd/  to be paid more money for your work than you should be paid:
examples: được trả cao hơn
▪ in my opinion, lawyers are overpaid and underworked.

children.name: pay b1
children.definition: pay/peɪ/  the money that you earn by working:
examples: ▪ ‘what’s the pay?’ ‘about $10 an hour.’
▪ the worst thing about being a nurse is the low pay.sick pay pay that you get when you are ill and cannot work
▪ joe’s been receiving sick pay since the accident.
paynoun[ u ]tiền lương
the money you receive for doing a job
_ukany payrise(us usuallyraise) must be in line with inflation.
_it's a nice job but the pay is appalling.

children.name: salary b1
children.definition: salary/ˈsæləri/  the money that someone is paideverymonthby their employer, especially someone who is in aprofession, such as a teacher or a manager:
examples: lương
a salary of £100,000/$10,000 etc
▪ the university provides a salary of $3,000 a month plus benefits.
▪ johansen reportedly earns an annual salary of $4 million.
be on a salarybe earning a salary
▪ i joined the company in 1985, on a salary of $22,000 a year.
a good/high salary
▪ our daughter makes a good salary, but she really works for it.
salarynoun[ c or u ]món tiền trả đều đặn (thường) là hàng tháng cho người làm công; tiền lương
a fixed amount of money agreed every year as pay for an employee, usually paid directly into his or her bank account every month
_anannualsalary of £20 000
_his netmonthlysalary is £1500.
_she'sonquite a good/decent salary in her present job.
_hetook a drop in(= accepted a lower) salary when he changed jobs.
_a 10% salaryincrease

children.name: wage b1
children.definition: wagealsowages/weɪdʒ, ˈweɪdʒz/  the money that someone is paideveryweekby their employer, especially someonewhoworks in a factory, shop etc:
examples: lương
▪ elvina earns an hourly wage of $11.
▪ without qualifications it’s nearly impossible to get a job with decent wages.
minimum wagethe lowest amount of money that can legally be paid per hour to a worker
▪ most of the new jobs in the area only pay the minimum wage.
wagenoun[ s ] (alsowages[ plural ] )tiền lương;tiền công
a fixed amount of money that is paid, usually every week, to an employee, especially one who does work that needs physical skills or strength, rather than a job needing a college education
_a very low/high wage
_an hourly/daily/weekly/annual wage
_he gets/earns/is paid a good wage, because he works for a fair employer.
_the smaller shops pay very low wages.

children.name: income b2
children.definition: income/ˈɪŋkʌm, ˈɪn-/  all the money that someone receives regularly, for example from their job, from their savings or from the government:
examples: thu nhập
▪ i’d love to know what his income is. he has so many new clothes and such an expensive car.
▪ we knew we’d need another source of income if we were planning to have a big family.
▪ couples with joint incomes over $50,000 are the fastest growing segment of the housing market.
income of $200/£400 etc
khoản thu nhập , lợi tức 200 đô la/400 bảng anh...
▪ the whole family survives on the mother’s monthly income of less than £500.
low income
thu nhập , lợi tức thấp
▪ if you are on a low income, you may be entitled to free dental treatment.
regular income;
lợi tức , thu nhập đều đặn
▪ she receives a regular income from the investments she made twenty years ago.
monthly/annual/weekly/yearly income
thu nhập , lợi tức hàng tháng/hàng năm/hàng tuần/hàng năm
▪ the average annual income in hong kong is now much higher than it was in 1994.
income/ˈɪŋkʌm, ˈɪn-/ [countable/uncountable noun] all the money that you receiveregularly, for work or for any other reason:
thu nhập
▪ braund’s annual income is just over $40,000.
▪ the amount of tax you have to pay depends on your income.be on a low income receive very little money
▪ families on low incomes are eligible for state benefits.income from
▪ richard has a comfortable income from his salary and his investments.
incomenoun[ c or u ]lợi tức;thu nhập
money that is earned from doing work or received frominvestments
_average incomes have risen by 4.5% over the past year.
_more help is needed for people onlowincomes.
_i haven't had much income from my stocks and shares this year.
disposable incomenoun[ u ]c2thu nhậpkhả dụng
the money which you can spend as you want and not the money which you spend on taxes, food and other basic needs

children.name: earnings b2
children.definition: earnings/ˈɜːʳnɪŋz/  thetotalamount of money you earn fromanyworkyou do:
examples: thu nhập
▪ most single mothers spend a large part of their earnings on childcare.
▪ the average worker’s earnings have not kept up with inflation.
earningsplural nountiền kiếm được, tiền lương; thu nhập
the amount of money that someone is paid for the work they do
average earnings for skilled workers are rising.

children.name: fee b1
children.definition: fee/fiː/  money paid to aprofessionalperson such as a doctor or lawyer for a piece of work:
examples: thù lao ( khi phải trả : khoản phí )
▪ dr allison charges a fee of $90 for a consultation.
▪ last year ibm paid $12 million in legal fees to a single law firm.
▪ the fee for the standard structural survey is £175.
hourly fee/rate, etc.
the amount that is charged or earned every hour

children.name: living b2
children.definition: livingnounjobsinh kế
examples: [ c ] the money that you earn from your job
_what do youdo for aliving (= what is your job) ?
_i mean, i don't like my job but at least it's a living (= a way of earning money) .
_you can make agoodliving (= earn a lot of money) in sales if you have the right attitude.

children.name: hourly fee/rate, etc. b2
children.definition: hourly fee/rate, etc.
examples: the amount that is charged or earned every hour

children.name: revenue c1
children.definition: revenuenoun (alsorevenues)
examples: thu nhập (nhất là tổng số thu nhập hàng năm của nhà nước từ thuế)
the income that a government or company receives regularly
_taxes provide most of the government's revenue.
_government revenues fell dramatically.

children.name: not earn anything for work that you do
unpaid c1
children.definition: unpaid/ˌʌnˈpeɪd◂/  anunpaidworkerdoes not get paid for the work that he or she does;
examples: ▪ amir worked as an unpaid informant for the internal security service
▪ coburn works 20 to 25 unpaid hours a week for the organization.
unpaid worker/volunteer etc
perry stayed on with the agency as an unpaid adviser.

children.name: to get money for your work
gross x
children.definition: gross/grəʊs/ especiallyamericanto earn a particular amount of moneyeach year,beforetaxhas been taken away - use this especially to talk aboutcompaniesorbusinessesmaking money:
examples: kiếm được cả thảy
▪ jack grosses $58,000 a year, but he has to pay taxes and health insurance out of that.
▪ walmax, a california superstore, grosses more than eight million dollars annually.
gross over/more than
▪ if you gross over $100,000, you should consult a good tax accountant.

children.name: earn a2
children.definition: earn/ɜːʳn/  to be paid a particular amount of money for your work, especially over a period of time -earn is more formal than make or get:
examples: ▪ at the peak of his career, rogers was earning more than seven million dollars a year.
▪ it’s not uncommon nowadays for women to earn more than their husbands.
earn £15,000 per year/$15 an hour etc
▪ alan earns $30,000 a year.
earn/ɜːʳn/ [transitive verb] to make a profit frombusinessor fromputtingmoneyin a bank,lendingit to a company etc:
kiếm được
▪ the washington post company earned $187 million in 1987.
▪ our finances look better if we include the profit earned on the sale of our london offices.
▪ she decided to put the money in a high-earning investment account.
earnverb[ i or t ]kiếm sống; kiếm được tiền
to receive money as payment for work that you do
_i earn $30 000 a year.
_how much do you earn, if you don't mind me asking?
_you can't expect to earna living(= be paid enough money to live on) from your painting.
_[ + two objects ]coffee exports earn (= give)brazilmany millions of pounds a year./brazil earns many millions of pounds a yearfromcoffee exports.

children.name: make b1
children.definition: make/meɪk/  to be paid a particular amount of money for your work, especiallya lot of money:
examples: ▪ ella makes a lot of money.
▪ how much to you think he makes?
make $500 a week/£25,000 per year etc
▪ some models make millions of dollars a year.
make/meɪk/ [transitive verb] to get a profit, especiallyfrombusiness deals:
make £1 million/$10,000 etc
▪ british telecom made over $3 billion last year.
make money
▪ the restaurant makes a lot of money in the summer.
make money doing something
▪ you could make a lot of money selling your photographs, they’re excellent.
make millions/make a fortune
▪ mandon, our richest cousin, had made a fortune in the cable tv business.
make out of
▪ the entrepreneur boasted that he could make money out of anything, even pebbles in the beach.
makeverbmade,madeearn/getlàm
[ t ] to earn or get
_she makes $100 000 a year as a doctor.
_how do you makea livingas a painter?
_the company has made huge profits/losses.
_he's very good at making new friends.

children.name: get a1
children.definition: get/get/ informalto earn a particular amount of moneyeveryhour, week etc:
examples: get £10 per hour/$350 dollars a week etc
▪ my sister gets $22 an hour at her new job.
▪ how much are you getting a week?
get $25/£15 etc for doing something

children.name: be paid/get paid b1
children.definition: be paid/get paid/biː ˈpeɪd, get ˈpeɪd/  to earn money when you work for an employer and not for yourself:
examples: được trả
be paid £50/$200 etc
▪ city maintenance workers are paid around $250 a week.
▪ we get paid every two weeks.

children.name: be on u
children.definition: be on/biː ˈɒn/  britishinformalto earn a particular amount of moneyeachyear:
examples: ▪ claire’s on a very good salary.
▪ in january, i’ll be on £23,350.
▪ how much were you on in your last job?

children.name: to earn enough for the things that you need
earn/make a living b2
children.definition: earn/make a living/ˌɜːʳn, ˌmeɪk ə ˈlɪvɪŋ/  to earn enough money to pay for the things that you or your family need:
examples: kiếm đủ sống
earn/make a living by doing something
▪ as an engineer, you can earn a living anywhere in the world.
▪ it’s difficult to make a living as a writer.
▪ nordstrom earned his living by teaching violin.
earn a good/decent livingearn more than enough
▪ a programmer earns a pretty decent living.

children.name: support your family b1
children.definition: support yourself/your family/səˌpɔːʳt jɔːʳˈself, jɔːʳ ˈfæməli/  to pay for the things that you or your family need out of the money that you earn, especially when you are theonly person in the family who is earning money:
examples: nuối sống gia đình, nuôi sống bản thân
▪ after his father died, peter had to quit school and support the family.
▪ hank supported himself for years by doing construction work.
▪ i have no idea how he’s supporting himself.

children.name: earn your keep x
children.definition: earn your keep/ˌɜːʳn jɔːʳ ˈkiːp/  to earn enough money to pay for your food and other needs, especially when someone has been supporting you until now:
examples: tự nuôi sống mình
▪ it’s time you got a job and started earning your keep.

children.name: money that you earn in addition to your usual pay
overtime x
children.definition: overtime/ˈəʊvəʳtaɪm/  money that is paid to someone for additional hours that they have worked:
examples: tiền tăng ca
▪ last week alex earned $300, including ten hours of overtime.
▪ teachers never get paid overtime.

children.name: bonus b2
children.definition: bonus/ˈbəʊnəs/  money added to someone’s pay, especially as arewardfor good work:
examples: tiền thưởng
▪ liz earned a £1000 bonus for being the best salesperson of the year.
▪ the management offered a large bonus to those workers who stayed to the end of the contract.
bonusnoun[ c ]tiền thưởng
an extra amount of money that is given to you as a present or reward as well as the money you were expecting
_a productivity bonus
_a christmas bonus
_the company used to give discretionary bonus payments.

children.name: commission x
children.definition: commission/kəˈmɪʃən/  money earned by someone whose job is tosellthings, based on the value of what they sell:
examples: tiền hoa hồng
▪ his basic salary is low, but he gets 20% commission on everything he sells.
be on commissionreceive commission every time you sell something
▪ most insurance agents are on commission, and some earn a lot of money.

children.name: tip b1
children.definition: tip/tɪp/  a small amount of money in addition to theordinary payment, which you give to someone such as awaiterortaxi-driver:
examples: ▪ the boy carried my suitcases up to my room and then stood waiting for a tip.
▪ we finished our lunch and left a tip on the table for the waiter.
tip[transitive verb] give someone a tip:
▪ she tipped the taxi-driver.
tipnoun[ c ]paymenttiền quà, tiền diêm thuốc
a small amount of money given to someone who has provided you with a service, in addition to the official payment and for their personal use
_a 15% tip
_hegavethe porter a tip.
_we don't need toleavea tipforthe waiter, because there's a service charge included in the bill.

children.name: fringe benefits x
children.definition: fringe benefits/ˌfrɪndʒ ˈbenfɪts/  the additional things such as holiday pay, free food, or free health insurance, which a worker receives in addition to their pay:
examples: phụ cấp
▪ the salary isn’t very high, but fringe benefits include free health insurance and a company car.

children.name: perk x
children.definition: perk/pɜːʳk/  something valuable or enjoyable that you get from your workapart from pay, especially something you getunofficially:
examples: bổng lộc, lợi ích ( không quy ra tiền )
▪ one of the perks of working for a fashion designer is that you get to wear lots of nice clothes.
▪ it’s not always fun being an air hostess, but the perks are good.
▪ the professors regard foreign travel as a perk, and they go to all the international conferences.

children.name: workers that not earn much money
low-paid x
children.definition: low-paid/ˌləʊ ˈpeɪd◂/ low-paid workersdo not earn much money for their work.low-paid workis work that people do not get paid much money for:
examples: ▪ a low-paid mechanic
low-paid job
▪ the jobs centre seems to list only low-paid temporary jobs.

children.name: be badly-paid x
children.definition: be badly-paid/biː ˌbædli ˈpeɪd/  ifsomeoneis badly paid, they do not earn much money for their work - use this when you think someone should earn much more money:
examples: ▪ a lot of people think that nurses are badly-paid.

children.name: get peanuts x
children.definition: get peanuts/work for peanuts/get ˈpiːnʌts, ˌwɜːʳk fəʳ ˈpiːnʌts/  informal to be paid very little money:
examples: được trả 1 số tiền nhỏ
▪ jobs are so hard to find that people are willing to work for peanuts.

children.name: slave labour x
children.definition: slave labourbritish /slave laboramerican /ˌsleɪv ˈleɪbəʳ/  if you say thatwhat someone is paidis slave labour, you mean that they are paid very little money even though they have to work extremely hard, and this isunfair:
examples: ▪ £50 a week? that’s slave labour!
▪ working for them is slave labor - they only pay five bucks an hour.

children.name: the breadwinner x
children.definition: the breadwinner/ðə ˈbredwɪnəʳ/  the person in a family who earns most of the money that the family needs:
examples: trụ cột gia đình
▪ many people still expect the man to be the breadwinner.

children.name: wage-earner x
children.definition: người làm công ăn lương
examples: wage-earner/ˈweɪdʒ ˌɜːʳnəʳ/ [countable noun] someone who has a job and earns wages:
▪ jim is the family’s main wage earner.
▪ families without wage-earners must seek relief from government social security programs.

children.name: low pay u
children.definition: low pay/ˌləʊ ˈpeɪ/
examples: ▪ low pay is one of the disadvantages of working in publishing.
▪ these jobs are unattractive because of low pay and inadequate training.

children.name: a pittance x
children.definition: a pittance/ə ˈpɪtəns/  anunfairlysmall amount of money paid to someone for their work:
examples: tiền thù lao rẻ mạt
▪ in the 19th century, children worked long hours in factories for a pittance.
▪ compared to what some people earn, my salary is a pittance.

children.name: peanuts x
children.definition: peanuts/ˈpiːnʌts/ informalanunfairlysmall amount of money paid to someone for their work:
examples: ▪ ‘it’s not fair,’ she said. ‘he pays me peanuts, and he expects me to work late as well.’

children.name: to earn an amount of money after tax etc has been taken away
take home x
children.definition: take home/ˌteɪk ˈhəʊm/  to earn a certain amount of money, after tax etc has been taken away from your pay:
examples: mang về nhà
▪ lidia takes home only about $150 a week.
▪ did you know that plumbers can take home as much as $40,000 a year?
take-home pay/ˈteɪk həʊm ˌpeɪ/ [noun phrase] the pay remaining after tax has been taken away:
▪ my dad’s take-home pay was around £50 a week when he first started out.

children.name: net x
children.definition: net/net/  to earn a particular amount of money as a profit after tax has been paid - use this especially to talk aboutcompaniesorbusinessesmaking money:
examples: kiếm được
▪ for the first three months of 1990, starcorp netted $547 million.
▪ donna got a raise in february, but she’s still only netting $19,000 a year.

children.name: clear x
children.definition: clear/klɪəʳ/  to earn a particular amount of money after tax etc has been taken away, especiallyin a job where you work for yourself:
examples: thu được kiếm được ( từ công việc kinh doanh riêng )
▪ sandra cleared £50,000 last year.
▪ a good lawyer can clear $250,000 a year easily.

children.name: pay rise c1
children.definition: pay risenounuk(uspay raise)
examples: an increase in the fixed amount of money you earn for doing your job
